notes:
1. Definition

An isobaric process is a thermodynamic process in which the pressure remains constant: $\Delta P = 0$.

2. Work Done

Since the pressure is constant, the calculation of boundary work simplifies:

$$W = \int_{V_1}^{V_2} P dV = P \int_{V_1}^{V_2} dV = P(V_2 - V_1) = P\Delta V$$

3. First Law of Thermodynamics

The first law is $\Delta U = Q - W$. Substituting the expression for work:

$$\Delta U = Q - P\Delta V$$

For an isobaric process, the heat transferred to the system is equal to the change in enthalpy ($\Delta H$).

$$Q = \Delta H$$

4. P-V Diagram

On a Pressure-Volume (P-V) diagram, an isobaric process appears as a horizontal straight line. The area under this line represents the work done.

solvedExamples.question: During an isobaric process, which property of the system remains constant?
solvedExamples.explanation: The definition of an isobaric process is one that occurs at constant pressure.

solvedExamples.question: A gas in a piston-cylinder device expands from a volume of 0.1 m³ to 0.3 m³ at a constant pressure of 200 kPa. How much work is done by the gas?
solvedExamples.explanation: Work done in an isobaric process is $W = P\Delta V$. $W = (200 \text{ kPa})(0.3 \text{ m³} - 0.1 \text{ m³}) = (200 \text{ kPa})(0.2 \text{ m³}) = 40 \text{ kJ}$.

solvedExamples.question: For an isobaric process, the heat transferred is equal to the change in what property?
solvedExamples.explanation: A key relationship for an isobaric process is that the heat transferred ($Q$) is equal to the change in enthalpy ($\Delta H$). This is because $Q = \Delta U + P\Delta V$, and enthalpy is defined as $H = U + PV$, so $\Delta H = \Delta U + \Delta(PV) = \Delta U + P\Delta V$ for constant pressure.
